elements.content: A ZnII-based metal–organic framework (MOF) with a rare tcj topology has been solvothermally synthesized and displays relatively good thermal and chemical stabilities. Interestingly, the MOF can sensitively and selectively sense acetylacetone (acac) via a fluorescence enhancement effect with a detection limit of 0.10 ppm and good reusability, which demonstrates the first example of a MOF-based turn-on fluorescent sensor for acac.
elements.clean_text: A ZnII-based metal-organic framework (MOF) with a rare tcj topology has been solvothermally synthesized and displays relatively good thermal and chemical stabilities. Interestingly, the MOF can sensitively and selectively sense acetylacetone (acac) via a fluorescence enhancement effect with a detection limit of 0.10 ppm and good reusability, which demonstrates the first example of a MOF-based turn-on fluorescent sensor for acac.

elements.content: A three-dimensional 1,3-bis­(benzimidazolyl)­benzene-based ZnII-based metal−organic framework (MOF) with a rare tcj topology exhibits a highly sensitive and selective detection to acetylacetone (acac) with a low detection limit of 0.10 ppm and a favorable recycling performance, which represents the first example of a MOF-based turn-on fluorescent sensor for acac.
elements.clean_text: A three-dimensional 1,3-bis(benzimidazolyl)benzene-based ZnII-based metal-organic framework (MOF) with a rare tcj topology exhibits a highly sensitive and selective detection to acetylacetone (acac) with a low detection limit of 0.10 ppm and a favorable recycling performance, which represents the first example of a MOF-based turn-on fluorescent sensor for acac.

elements.content: Because of their tunable properties and ever-expanding applications in catalysis, gas storage and separation, drug delivery, sensing, and magnetism, metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have become a hot research topic in the eyes of many chemists and material scientists. In recent years, there has been ever-increasing interest in the recognition and sensing of small organic molecules, which play key roles in the protection of the environment and human health. Compared with various detection methods, fluorescence sensing for detecting organic molecules with the remarkable superiorities of low cost, rapid response, high sensitivity, and efficiency has attracted extensive attention and has been rapidly developed. To date, MOFs as fluorescent sensors usually probe analyte via fluorescence quenching (turn-off fluorescence), fluorescence enhancement (turn-on fluorescence), or fluorescence shift. Among them, turn-off fluorescence is the most common, while turn-on fluorescence and fluorescence shift have been less reported. Therefore, the preparation of MOFs as turn-on fluorescent sensors with higher sensitivity and easier detection is extremely worthy.
elements.clean_text: Because of their tunable properties and ever-expanding applications in catalysis, gas storage and separation, drug delivery, sensing, and magnetism, metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have become a hot research topic in the eyes of many chemists and material scientists. In recent years, there has been ever-increasing interest in the recognition and sensing of small organic molecules, which play key roles in the protection of the environment and human health. Compared with various detection methods, fluorescence sensing for detecting organic molecules with the remarkable superiorities of low cost, rapid response, high sensitivity, and efficiency has attracted extensive attention and has been rapidly developed. To date, MOFs as fluorescent sensors usually probe analyte via fluorescence quenching (turn-off fluorescence), fluorescence enhancement (turn-on fluorescence), or fluorescence shift. Among them, turn-off fluorescence is the most common, while turn-on fluorescence and fluorescence shift have been less reported. Therefore, the preparation of MOFs as turn-on fluorescent sensors with higher sensitivity and easier detection is extremely worthy.

elements.content: As far as we know, acetylacetone (acac) is extensively employed in organic synthetic intermediates, analytical reagents, and other essential raw ingredients, such as the precursor for organic synthesis, chelating agent, or modifier in the sol–gel method, as a nonaqueous redox-flow battery, as a new absorbent for the removal of formaldehyde, and so forth. However, as a toxic, volatile, and combustible chemical, acac is perilous when exposed to air and causes severe environmental problems and human diseases such as dizziness, sicchasia, unconscious, and so on. Therefore, the sensing of acac is extremely imperative and requires an effective material with high sensitivity and selectivity. To the best of our knowledge, only four kinds of MOF materials for the detection of acac have been reported, which are detected through turn-off fluorescence. However, the MOF used as a turn-on fluorescent sensor for acac has never been reported. Therefore, the preparation of MOFs as turn-on fluorescent sensors for acac is meaningful.
elements.clean_text: As far as we know, acetylacetone (acac) is extensively employed in organic synthetic intermediates, analytical reagents, and other essential raw ingredients, such as the precursor for organic synthesis, chelating agent, or modifier in the sol-gel method, as a nonaqueous redox-flow battery, as a new absorbent for the removal of formaldehyde, and so forth. However, as a toxic, volatile, and combustible chemical, acac is perilous when exposed to air and causes severe environmental problems and human diseases such as dizziness, sicchasia, unconscious, and so on. Therefore, the sensing of acac is extremely imperative and requires an effective material with high sensitivity and selectivity. To the best of our knowledge, only four kinds of MOF materials for the detection of acac have been reported, which are detected through turn-off fluorescence. However, the MOF used as a turn-on fluorescent sensor for acac has never been reported. Therefore, the preparation of MOFs as turn-on fluorescent sensors for acac is meaningful.

elements.content: Herein, 1,3-bis­(benzimidazolyl)­benzene (bbib) and 1,4-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid (H2ndc) are chosen as organic ligands to synthesize fluorescent MOFs (Scheme S1) for the following reasons. (1) The large conjugated π-electron system is in favor of emitting strong luminescence. (2) H2ndc with various coordination modes is conducive to constructing MOFs with attractive structures and properties. To date, some discrete compounds derived from the bbib ligand have been studied, but bbib-based coordination polymers have rarely been reported. A new three-dimensional (3D) framework {[Zn3(bbib)2(ndc)3]·2DMF·2H2O} n (1; DMF = N,N-dimethylformamide) has been synthesized under solvothermal condition (see the Experimental Section in the Supporting Information). Complex 1 takes a 4,6-c net with tcj topology, and the framework exhibits relatively good thermal and solvent stabilities. The fluorescent studies indicate that 1 could selectively sense acac with a low detection limit of 0.10 ppm, which is the first case of MOF as a turn-on fluorescence sensor for acac.
elements.clean_text: Herein, 1,3-bis(benzimidazolyl)benzene (bbib) and 1,4-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid (H2ndc) are chosen as organic ligands to synthesize fluorescent MOFs (Scheme S1) for the following reasons. (1) The large conjugated π-electron system is in favor of emitting strong luminescence. (2) H2ndc with various coordination modes is conducive to constructing MOFs with attractive structures and properties. To date, some discrete compounds derived from the bbib ligand have been studied, but bbib-based coordination polymers have rarely been reported. A new three-dimensional (3D) framework {[Zn3(bbib)2(ndc)3]⋅2DMF⋅2H2O} n  (1; DMF = N,N-dimethylformamide) has been synthesized under solvothermal condition (see the Experimental Section in the Supporting Information). Complex 1 takes a 4,6-c net with tcj topology, and the framework exhibits relatively good thermal and solvent stabilities. The fluorescent studies indicate that 1 could selectively sense acac with a low detection limit of 0.10 ppm, which is the first case of MOF as a turn-on fluorescence sensor for acac.

elements.content: Crystallographic studies show that 1 belongs to the C2/c space group of the monoclinic system, and the asymmetric unit is composed of one and a half of ZnII, one and a half of ndc2– ligands, one bbib ligand, one DMF molecule, and one H2O molecule. The crystallographically independent ZnII ions present different coordinated geometries. Zn1 has a five-coordinate environment consisting of four O atoms (O1A, O2, O5, and O6A) from the carboxylates of four ndc2– ligands and one N atom (N1) of one bbib ligand (a). In addition, Zn1 and Zn1A ions constitute a [Zn2(COO)4] paddle-wheel secondary building unit, and the distance of Zn···Zn is 2.973(10) Å. Zn2 has a six-coordinate environment, which is surrounded by four O atoms (O3C, O4C, O3D, and O4D) from the carboxylates of two ndc2– ligands and two N atoms (N4 and N4B) from the bbib ligand. The coordination geometries of Zn1 and Zn2 could be viewed as spherical square pyramid and octahedron, respectively, calculated by the software SHAPE 2.1 (Table S3). The Zn–O and Zn–N bond distances are 2.022(4)–2.414(9) and 2.014(5)–2.047(5) Å, respectively (Table S2). The paddle-wheel binuclear building block and mononuclear unit are linked by the carboxylates to constitute a two-dimensional (2D) layer structure (Figure S1), which is further connected by bbib ligands to obtain a 3D framework (b). Besides, ndc2– ligands in 1 adopt bidentate chelating, bidentate, and bridging bis-bidentate modes (Figure S2). Topological analysis of 1 indicates that a 2-nodal tcj topology with the Schlafli symbol {44.610.8}­{44.62} can be rationalized by TOPOS 4.0 if mononuclear and binuclear units are considered to be 4- and 6-connected nodes, respectively (c). The total solvent-accessible volume estimated by PLATON of 1 is 7641.2 Å3, and the porosity is 21.4% of the unit cell without solvent molecules.
elements.clean_text: Crystallographic studies show that 1 belongs to the C2/c space group of the monoclinic system, and the asymmetric unit is composed of one and a half of ZnII, one and a half of ndc2- ligands, one bbib ligand, one DMF molecule, and one H2O molecule. The crystallographically independent ZnII ions present different coordinated geometries. Zn1 has a five-coordinate environment consisting of four O atoms (O1A, O2, O5, and O6A) from the carboxylates of four ndc2- ligands and one N atom (N1) of one bbib ligand (a). In addition, Zn1 and Zn1A ions constitute a [Zn2(COO)4] paddle-wheel secondary building unit, and the distance of Zn⋅⋅⋅Zn is 2.973(10) Å. Zn2 has a six-coordinate environment, which is surrounded by four O atoms (O3C, O4C, O3D, and O4D) from the carboxylates of two ndc2- ligands and two N atoms (N4 and N4B) from the bbib ligand. The coordination geometries of Zn1 and Zn2 could be viewed as spherical square pyramid and octahedron, respectively, calculated by the software SHAPE 2.1  (Table S3). The Zn-O and Zn-N bond distances are 2.022(4)-2.414(9) and 2.014(5)-2.047(5) Å, respectively (Table S2). The paddle-wheel binuclear building block and mononuclear unit are linked by the carboxylates to constitute a two-dimensional (2D) layer structure (Figure S1), which is further connected by bbib ligands to obtain a 3D framework (b). Besides, ndc2- ligands in 1 adopt bidentate chelating, bidentate, and bridging bis-bidentate modes (Figure S2). Topological analysis of 1 indicates that a 2-nodal tcj topology with the Schlafli symbol {44.610.8}{44.62} can be rationalized by TOPOS 4.0  if mononuclear and binuclear units are considered to be 4- and 6-connected nodes, respectively (c). The total solvent-accessible volume estimated by PLATON  of 1 is 7641.2 Å3, and the porosity is 21.4% of the unit cell without solvent molecules.

elements.content: Views of (a) the coordination environment of ZnII in 1, (b) the 3D structure of 1, and (c) the tcj topological structure of 1. Symmetry codes: A, −x + 1/2, −y + 3/2, −z; B, −x + 1, y, −z + 1/2; C, −x + 1/2, −y + 1/2, −z; D, x + 1/2, −y + 1/2, z + 1/2.
elements.clean_text: 1  Views of (a) the coordination environment of ZnII in 1, (b) the 3D structure of 1, and (c) the tcj topological structure of 1. Symmetry codes: A, -x + 1/2, -y + 3/2, -z; B, -x + 1, y, -z + 1/2; C, -x + 1/2, -y + 1/2, -z; D, x + 1/2, -y + 1/2, z + 1/2.

elements.content: MOFs constructed from ZnII ions along with conjugated organic ligands are considered to be promising choices as fluorescent materials. The solid fluorescence spectra of bbib, H2ndc, and 1 were measured at room temperature. As shown in Figures S3 and S4, the emission band for bbib is observed at 328 nm (λex = 280 nm). The H2ndc ligand exhibits fluorescence emission at 485 nm (λex = 375 nm). A double bond consisting of σ and π bonds and the emission of organic ligands are usually attributed to π* → π and/or π* → n electronic transitions. Complex 1 gives a strong emission band at 399 nm (λex = 361 nm). Presumably, the emission for 1 should be attributed to metal-perturbed intraligand charge transfer due to the d10 electron configuration of ZnII. The obvious blue shift of the band compared to the H2ndc ligand may have resulted from metal–ligand coordination interactions. Furthermore, different coordination environments have a significant impact on the fluorescence emission of 1. From the fluorescence decay curve (Figure S5), the fluorescence lifetime of 1 is 9.57 μs.
elements.clean_text: MOFs constructed from ZnII ions along with conjugated organic ligands are considered to be promising choices as fluorescent materials. The solid fluorescence spectra of bbib, H2ndc, and 1 were measured at room temperature. As shown in Figures S3 and S4, the emission band for bbib is observed at 328 nm (λex = 280 nm). The H2ndc ligand exhibits fluorescence emission at 485 nm (λex = 375 nm). A double bond consisting of σ and π bonds and the emission of organic ligands are usually attributed to π* → π and/or π* → n electronic transitions. Complex 1 gives a strong emission band at 399 nm (λex = 361 nm). Presumably, the emission for 1 should be attributed to metal-perturbed intraligand charge transfer due to the d10 electron configuration of ZnII. The obvious blue shift of the band compared to the H2ndc ligand may have resulted from metal-ligand coordination interactions. Furthermore, different coordination environments have a significant impact on the fluorescence emission of 1. From the fluorescence decay curve (Figure S5), the fluorescence lifetime of 1 is 9.57 μs.

elements.content: The fluorescence detection experiments of different small organic molecules were carried out with the DMF suspension of 1. Because 1 includes DMF molecules and exhibits good stability in DMF solution, DMF is chosen as the dispersion medium. The 2 mg fully ground sample was dispersed in 2 mL of DMF and ultrasonicated for 0.5 h, which leads to a stable suspension solution. For fluorescence studies, 5 μL portions of distinct organic solvents containing alcohols (methanol, ethanol, 1-propanol, and 2-propanol), ketones (acetone and acac), chloroalkanes (dichloromethane, trichloromethane, and tetrachloromethane), amide (dimethylacetamide), ethers (tetrahydrofuran, acetonitrile, and cyclohexane), and other aromatic compounds (benzene, toluene, p-xylene, m-xylene, o-xylene) were dropped into 2 mL amounts of the suspension solution, respectively. The fluorescence intensities of 1 significantly depend on the solvent molecules (a). Notably, it exhibits the most remarkable turn-on fluorescence after the addition of acac. The suspension of 1 with 2500 ppm acac transferred the visual emission color from light blue to blue when excited by 365 nm with a UV lamp, which allows the detection of acac by the naked eye. However, other solvents have ignorable influences on the emission intensities. Hence, 1 could act as a promising chemsensor of acac via the turn-on effect. In view of the high selectivity of 1 toward acac, anti-interference experiments were recorded with the presence of 1 equiv of other organics. The fluorescence response of 1 toward acac is almost undisturbed by other solvents (b). The results demonstrate that 1 could be used as a fluorescence sensor for acac with high sensitivity and efficient selectivity.

For fluorescence studies, 5 μL portions of distinct organic solvents containing alcohols (methanol, ethanol, 1-propanol, and 2-propanol), ketones (acetone and acac), chloroalkanes (dichloromethane, trichloromethane, and tetrachloromethane), amide (dimethylacetamide), ethers (tetrahydrofuran, acetonitrile, and cyclohexane), and other aromatic compounds (benzene, toluene, p-xylene, m-xylene, o-xylene) were dropped into 2 mL amounts of the suspension solution, respectively. The suspension of 1 with 2500 ppm acac transferred the visual emission color from light blue to blue when excited by 365 nm with a UV lamp, which allows the detection of acac by the naked eye. The fluorescence response of 1 toward acac is almost undisturbed by other solvents (b). The results demonstrate that 1 could be used as a fluorescence sensor for acac with high sensitivity and efficient selectivity.

elements.content: (a) Fluorescence intensity of 1 scattered in DMF upon the dropping of different organics with a concentration of 2500 ppm. (b) Fluorescence intensity ratio histograms of 1 dispersed in DMF with the dropping of different solvents (red) and subsequent dropping of acac (green). (c) Fluorescence intensity of 1 in DMF suspension with different concentrations of acac at room temperature (λex = 361 nm).
elements.clean_text: 2  (a) Fluorescence intensity of 1 scattered in DMF upon the dropping of different organics with a concentration of 2500 ppm. (b) Fluorescence intensity ratio histograms of 1 dispersed in DMF with the dropping of different solvents (red) and subsequent dropping of acac (green). (c) Fluorescence intensity of 1 in DMF suspension with different concentrations of acac at room temperature (λex = 361 nm).

elements.content: To explore the detection limit of 1 as a chemsensor for probing acac, the fluorescence titration spectra were performed by gradually increasing the concentration of 1% acac. The fluorescence intensity of 1 is gradually enhanced with the constant addition of acac (c), which suggests the turn-on fluorescence of 1. The correlation between the emission intensity ratios [(I 0/I) – 1] and the concentration of acac is represented in Figure S6, and the result demonstrates a good linear correlation (R = 0.988). Additionally, the detection limit calculated by the formula 3σ/k (σ = standard error; k = slope) is 0.10 ppm (Figure S6), which is comparable to the values (1.72, 0.647, and 0.25 ppm) of other acac sensors. Therefore, 1 has good sensitivity toward acac.
elements.clean_text: To explore the detection limit of 1 as a chemsensor for probing acac, the fluorescence titration spectra were performed by gradually increasing the concentration of 1% acac. The fluorescence intensity of 1 is gradually enhanced with the constant addition of acac (c), which suggests the turn-on fluorescence of 1. The correlation between the emission intensity ratios [(I 0/I) - 1] and the concentration of acac is represented in Figure S6, and the result demonstrates a good linear correlation (R = 0.988). Additionally, the detection limit calculated by the formula 3σ/k (σ = standard error; k = slope) is 0.10 ppm (Figure S6), which is comparable to the values (1.72, 0.647, and 0.25 ppm) of other acac sensors. Therefore, 1 has good sensitivity toward acac.

elements.content: The fluorescence response depending on the time was further measured. The fluorescence intensities of the suspensions with an acac concentration of 2500 ppm were continuously recorded (Figure S7). After 20 s, the fluorescence intensity exhibits an obvious enhancement. As time goes on, the fluorescent intensities slowly increase and reach 5.4 times at 720 s, which further confirms the high detection sensitivity of 1 toward acac.
elements.clean_text: The fluorescence response depending on the time was further measured. The fluorescence intensities of the suspensions with an acac concentration of 2500 ppm were continuously recorded (Figure S7). After 20 s, the fluorescence intensity exhibits an obvious enhancement. As time goes on, the fluorescent intensities slowly increase and reach 5.4 times at 720 s, which further confirms the high detection sensitivity of 1 toward acac.

elements.content: Indeed, the recycling capacity is meaningful for practical application in fluorescent sensing. Thus, it is essential to find a fast and simple method for recycling. Then, the recycling property of 1 was studied. The sample was simply immersed in 2500 ppm acac for a few minutes and repeatedly washed by ethanol. The fluorescence intensity changes slightly, and the powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns of recycled samples agree with the initial one (Figures S8 and S11e), indicating that the framework remains stable. Therefore, 1 could be recycled at least five times as a fluorescent sensor for acac.
elements.clean_text: Indeed, the recycling capacity is meaningful for practical application in fluorescent sensing. Thus, it is essential to find a fast and simple method for recycling. Then, the recycling property of 1 was studied. The sample was simply immersed in 2500 ppm acac for a few minutes and repeatedly washed by ethanol. The fluorescence intensity changes slightly, and the powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns of recycled samples agree with the initial one (Figures S8 and S11e), indicating that the framework remains stable. Therefore, 1 could be recycled at least five times as a fluorescent sensor for acac.

elements.content: Recently, MOF-based fluorescent sensors have been widely investigated. However, there are no explicit mechanisms at present. The possible reason for the turn-on fluorescence sensing mechanism is attempted. The PXRD patterns (Figure S11b) indicate that the framework is maintained when the sample is immersed in a DMF solution containing acac. Moreover, considering the poor porosity in 1, it is out of the question to incorporate guest molecules into the pores. Therefore, the turn-on sensing mechanism might not be attributed to guest-induced turn-on fluorescence. Acac could be well scattered in the supernatant of 1·DMF, which capacitates acac molecules adsorbed on the surface of the particles, promoting possible host–guest interactions. Furthermore, the fluorescence of ZnII-based MOFs is mostly from intraligand n−π* or π–π* charge transfer. The possibility of turn-on fluorescence may largely be explicated by the donor–acceptor electron-transfer mechanism. Generally, in the case in which the excited electrons are transferred from a high-lying π*-type lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) to the conduction band (CB) of 1, turn-on fluorescence will emerge. In addition, 1 shows an emission peak shift (400–408 nm) upon the addition of acac (Figure S9). The red shift observed in the fluorescence emission indicates strong exciplex formation between 1 and acac. Exciplexes are regarded as excited complexes, which generally emerged from the interaction of an excited molecule with an unexcited molecule. Therefore, for acac, the obvious enhancement in the emission intensity and the red shift of the emission wavelength suggest that the electrons may transfer from the LUMO of acac to the CB of 1, together with the formation of a strong exciplex between acac and 1.
elements.clean_text: Recently, MOF-based fluorescent sensors have been widely investigated. However, there are no explicit mechanisms at present. The possible reason for the turn-on fluorescence sensing mechanism is attempted. The PXRD patterns (Figure S11b) indicate that the framework is maintained when the sample is immersed in a DMF solution containing acac. Moreover, considering the poor porosity in 1, it is out of the question to incorporate guest molecules into the pores. Therefore, the turn-on sensing mechanism might not be attributed to guest-induced turn-on fluorescence. Acac could be well scattered in the supernatant of 1⋅DMF, which capacitates acac molecules adsorbed on the surface of the particles, promoting possible host-guest interactions. Furthermore, the fluorescence of ZnII-based MOFs is mostly from intraligand n-π* or π-π* charge transfer. The possibility of turn-on fluorescence may largely be explicated by the donor-acceptor electron-transfer mechanism. Generally, in the case in which the excited electrons are transferred from a high-lying π*-type lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) to the conduction band (CB) of 1, turn-on fluorescence will emerge. In addition, 1 shows an emission peak shift (400-408 nm) upon the addition of acac (Figure S9). The red shift observed in the fluorescence emission indicates strong exciplex formation between 1 and acac. Exciplexes are regarded as excited complexes, which generally emerged from the interaction of an excited molecule with an unexcited molecule. Therefore, for acac, the obvious enhancement in the emission intensity and the red shift of the emission wavelength suggest that the electrons may transfer from the LUMO of acac to the CB of 1, together with the formation of a strong exciplex between acac and 1.

elements.content: In conclusion, a new 3D fluorescent ZnII-based MOF derived from the bbib ligand has been successfully constructed and structurally characterized, which takes a unique 4,6-c net with tcj topology. Interestingly, the MOF material could detect acac with high sensitivity and selectivity, as well as a good recycling performance. Notably, 1 represents the first case of a MOF-based turn-on fluorescent probe for acac.

Interestingly, the MOF material could detect acac with high sensitivity and selectivity, as well as a good recycling performance. Notably, 1 represents the first case of a MOF-based turn-on fluorescent probe for acac.

metadata.title:
A ZnII-Based Metal–Organic Framework
with a Rare tcj Topology as a Turn-On Fluorescent
Sensor for Acetylacetone
